body: Hi @hmaarrfk our users are typically using this as an full project management software as well as DL based pose estimation; if you want headless you can `pip install deeplabcut` or use `pip install deeplabcut-docker`, which might better suit your use cases? https://deeplabcut.github.io/DeepLabCut/docs/docker.html

Hello. Thanks for the quick reply.

The pip installation works great! Thank you for making that easy!

I understand that the "full project management GUI" experience is critical to your users. I do not want to take that away in the slightest (I would also be happy to help on that front too looking into the problems I am facing here I found a few places that could use touchups on the GUI front that I am happy to contribute).

Unfortunately, as soon as we `import deeplabcut` into an other workflow that might want to use a different backend for matplotlib (for some interactive plotting), the statements in the `__init__.py` change which backend is used and causes very strange behavior. 

Please see the attached screenshot where a user may want to use matplotlib in a jupyter notebook, but gets strange behavior as soon as they introduce deeplabcut into their analysis pipeline.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/90008/137631595-f1bc5db1-ad19-4968-9b15-696115d3da72.png)

This leads to rather tricky behavior (bugs or "features") to debug.

Finally, the `try: expect` statement to attempt to detect the wx library is also rather difficult to deal with when working in a larger project. It means that the selected backend of the library now might 

I understand that your users are often running deeplabcut with the command:

```
python -m deeplabcut
```

I understand how critical this is.

I can help ensure that this workflow remains unchanged.

Most of what it will involve is delaying the calls:
```
    import wx

    mpl.use("WxAgg")
```

to the desired entry points of the GUI.

I know this isn't "easy" and there are likely many knock-on effects that I cannot appreciate easily. However, if you are willing to review a few targetted PRs, I would be glad to make them.

Thank you again for considering.

* [deeplabcut_as_library_issues.zip](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/files/7360101/deeplabcut_as_library_issues.zip) <---- notebook file compressed in zip demonstrating a possible issue.
.

thanks for the further info!

> However, if you are willing to review a few targetted PRs, I would be glad to make them.
 - great, understood, and def. happy to improve this/ review PRs, thanks for the offer!

Also just to give you a roadmap, we are dropping wxPython soon (by early Q1 of 2022) - it's been a pain for years, the alpha replacement demo is here, if you want to use (then just use dlc headless) in the meantime: https://github.com/DeepLabCut/napari-DeepLabCut.  In short, we will be moving to vispy.

vispy and qt ate great! i just hope that they survive long enough. 

we have enough trouble migrating to newer versions there too.

As for making the installation process easier. I think that conda packages for deeplabcut should be available pretty soon.

vispy has a large grant from CZI, I think it will be a good option. Could you elaborate? "I think that conda packages for deeplabcut should be available pretty soon." i.e., we don't want to package DLC on conda actually, we would like to stay with pip....

and just to reiterate, the docker version might be what you want ultimately

Yes the CZI has been quite active in moving Vispy and other packages in the scientific python environment forward. I think it will be greatly appreciated.

My general concern is not so much with vispy development, but more with widespread integration with other packages and larger system dependencies. Qt is quite painful to package, and has, over the years, grown to be larger and larger.

As for the the conda package. I'm requesting the following package to be merged into conda-forge
https://github.com/conda-forge/staged-recipes/pull/16559
Lets discuss that: https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/issues/1549
https://github.com/DeepLabCut/napari-DeepLabCut here is the new GUI @hmaarrfk - still happy to review a PR moving the `import wx  mpl.use("WxAgg")` is useful in the meantime.

Hello @MMathisLab and @hmaarrfk 
I am facing the exact issue as well, as I am trying to integrate DeepLabCut in a larger GUI project to do animal tracking.
Is there any progress on this issue/feature?

Thank you very much,
David
i've mostly just not installed wx with deeplabcut :/.

issue.title: WIP: Delay setting the matplotlib backend until the user asks to launch the GUI

repository.name: DeepLabCut
repository.description: Official implementation of DeepLabCut: Markerless pose estimation of user-defined features with deep learning for all animals incl. humans

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
This is my attempt at addressing users' ability to import their DeepLabCut environment in both a Jupyter noteook and using the provided GUI (which is really useful!) 

I still need to test it on a variety of configurations, but this makes `wx` a truely optional dependency, and doesn't affect the behavior of matplotlib until the user calls the GUI launching script.



Closes https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/issues/1548
